section.title: &s1;
section.para: If neurons deal with the contextual organization of information, it is the content that contains the information that we organize. While concepts deal with the inner, mental world, content represents the link to the outer world of text, images and sound; the world of media and communication. The activation of content is one of the most important motivations for the creation of context at all.

section.title: &s2;
section.para:
Content consists of explanations, examples and definitions of concepts used in learning environments, representing different aspects of the concept in question. It may also consist of physical or digital resources that have a representation in the system for lexical purposes. So the definition of content consists of two parts:
Designing a representation of a piece of content in the system. This must include meta-data on the content, such as type information, and the location of digital content or the identification of physical content. The idea is that you should be able to search for and choose content without having seen the content itself, only this description.
Associating such a content description with a concept or other type of neuron.
The ideas for the usage of content and aspects are carefully described in cid52, and will therefore not be repeated here.

section.title: &s3;
section.para:
The representation in the system of a piece of content is made completely inside the existing system by defining a neuron type content-description and letting each piece of content be represented by a neuron of this type. This type has the following attributes:
degree zero, i.e., no axons. This reflects the fact that this really is an atomic object in the system (even though perhaps not outside).
two data tags: URI, the value of which is the location of the content, and MIMEType, giving a MIME type for the object.
This way we know where and what the content is. All other information as to what the content is about, for whom it is suitable etc. must be specified in the meta-data, with standardized tags.
These neurons can then be linked to by other neurons just as usual, thereby fully incorporating the content into the system.

To allow the content neurons to be treated as the content of a specific concept, we use the axon type content of concepts, relations etc., to point to content description neurons. The content descriptions found at the other end of such an axon are interpreted as the content of that neuron.

section.title: &s4;
section.para:
The choice of MIME as a representation of type information for content follows very similar lines to the choice of URI as identifier format:
The existing MIME types immediately usable: text/plain, image/jpeg etc., as well as the probability of useful future standard types. MIME types have been proved useful and functional, not only in mail attachments, but notably also in the HTTP protocol, and seem to be the de facto standard for digital types.
The existing standardized encoding in ASCII text, making it universally usable, as well as the support in different programming environments that support HTTP. A not small part of this point is that users are actually a bit used to this type of identifiers.
The hierarchical structure of the types is interesting, but not as important as for URIs.
The possibility of defining your own types. In fact, it would not pose any problem to define types for physical resources as well. As an example: combined with a URI protocol designed for this purpose, one could define the type physical/postal-address with the URI pointing to a postal address.
Add something about Dublin Core resource types.
It is not difficult to argue that both the type and the location actually belongs in meta-data. This will be considered.

It may seem as a violation of the design principles for axons to let the content be an axon in many different types of neurons, as the content may not seem essential for its existence. This line of argumentation clearly has its points, and it is admitted that the implemented solution may not be the cleanest one; one could for example want another neuron linking a neuron to its content, to make both the neuron and the content independent of the link between them (this is why generalizations, for example, are separate neurons). This would allow you to add content to neurons you cannot modify, a not uninteresting feature.

On the other hand, there are two points speaking for our solution. The first is purely philosophical; consider that concepts actually are representations of a group of phenomena (see cid17), where the collection of content actually tries to describe the phenomena; it may after all seem that this content is essential for the existence of the concept, as the concept is a representation of what these pieces of content have in common.

The second point is that the idea of content is so central to the browser that one would almost want to create a completely separate structure much resembling the axon idea, solely in order to simplify the introduction of content. To reuse the existing functionality then seems like the better way to go. Ideas in this area would, however, be much appreciated.

It is interesting to note that content-description is one of the single neuron types that are completely self-contained from this point of view, as such a neuron itself does not contain any content. As a remark it might be interesting to allow content collections to facilitate multiple narration techniques, but that is another story.

The content description was originally a component on its own, as the system at that time was not general enough to allow it to be represented by the other components of the time. This had the sad consequence that the content was not really represented in the system as something possible to link to in any other way than as content. The current system introduces content as a full-worthy neuron which makes it possible to actually describe relations between content as concept maps as well as, as described above, to represent the relation of being content of a concept without having to introduce any new structures into the system. This has had further consequences in connection with Filters.

One problem with content arises when you try to link into a complex piece of content, such as this article. Currently, you will need to create one separate content description for each section you want to link to, which quickly becomes somewhat cumbersome, and in some way seems necessary. Instead, one could imagine putting extra information into the content role in the neurons having a piece of this articla as content. This way, this article would be represented by a single content description, and a link to this section could be a content axon with data urimodifier="ch-content-4.html"
The file name of this section, which would be a URI relative to the URI given in the content description. Note that this URI would (probably) necessarily be relative, but that it also may contain fragment identifiers. Other types of content-displayer-specific modifying are perfectly imaginable, such as command-line arguments for an application etc.

Note, however, that any type of meta-data modifying would be impossible (and unwanted). Thus, using such a system for this article would still not be a good idea, as each section needs separate meta-data markup to enable filtering. This could all be a server-side problem of generating content descriptions on the fly from their identifiers.
